29.text: Mt Gibb Project owned by Jindalee Resources Limited

33.text: The Mt Gibb project covers the interpreted southern extensions of the Forrestania greenstone

34.text: belt beneath transported soils. There is no evidence of previous exploration in the area. The

35.text: project is a joint venture with Great Western Exploration Limited. Jindalee's 20% interest in the

36.text: project is free-carried to completion of a bankable feasibility study.

text:
The closest nickel mineralisation is 14km to the east called Mt Gibb (red outline on previous 
 geology image) owned by a Great Western Exploration. They have found an 8km extension to 
 the south of the Forrestania belt. The 2005 drilling program said “achieving significant nickel 
 and gold intersections beneath the concealing cover of a shallow dipping granite sheet 
 overlying the greenstone belt.” Further details in following section. 
 The Athena tenement appears to have had no historic exploration because of the soil cover, 
 colluvium and wind blown sands concealing much of the tenement making it ideal farming 
 land. The magnetic target is not in the same direction as the other two greenstone belts, and 
 any prospective rocks could be covered with granite sills. A historical tenement search in this 
 area shows that the majority of pegging was done around Hatters Hill for gold. 
 Roadside inspection of the tenement showed wind blown cover and gneissic outcrops. An 
 agreement would need to be signed with the owner as it is freehold land under wheat crop. 
 This access would enable initial geological mapping, geochemical soil surveys and a detailed 
 aeromagnetic survey after cropping season. 
 Before EM surveys are planned, the detailed aeromagnetics is required to fully understand the 
 target and whether to relinquish prior to further expenditure. The 400m aeromagnetic data is 
 too coarse and was flown in the wrong direction for this target, so true widths and depths can 
 not be estimated. 
 Neighbouring Tenements 
 Mt Gibb Project owned by Jindalee Resources Limited 
 Text extracted from http://www.jindalee.net/index.php?page=38 
 The Mt Gibb project covers the interpreted southern extensions of the Forrestania greenstone 
 belt beneath transported soils. There is no evidence of previous exploration in the area. The 
 project is a joint venture with Great Western Exploration Limited. Jindalee's 20% interest in the 
 project is free-carried to completion of a bankable feasibility study.

37.text: Nova explored the Hatter Hill area between 1984 and 1994 for gold. Activities included

38.text: geological mapping, ground magnetic surveys and RC drilling. Gold mineralisation was

39.text: reported as being within northeast-trending shear zones enclosing quartz veins and stockwork

40.text: veins. A resource of 120,000 tonnes at 5.0g/t Au was reported but estimated resource grades

41.text: were not repeated in trial mining.

43.text: From 1987 to 1991, GMK explored the area with activities including soil and auger sampling,

44.text: mapping, some magnetic surveys and percussion drilling. The auger sampling program south

45.text: of Hatter Hill, along lines oriented northeast-southwest 400m apart with sample spacing at

46.text: 40m, identified anomalous gold values and led to the drilling of 92 holes in three locations.

48.text: In the three drilling areas results above 1g/t Au were recorded as follows:

text:
nickel with best individual results including 10m @ 0.32% Ni from 30m, 5m @ 0.2% Ni from 
 40m and 5m @ 0.31% Ni from 30m. The best gold result was an ore grade intersection of 5m 
 @ 3.3g/t from 5m.  
 Historically, Aztec carried out exploration including geological mapping, soil sampling, an 
 airborne magnetic and radiometric survey within the region of Hatter Hill between 1989 and 
 1993. Much of the exploration was over granitoid terrain but RAB drilling over the granite-
 greenstone contact included reported intersections up to 1m averaging 2.2g/t gold. No follow-
 up exploration was undertaken.  
 Nova explored the Hatter Hill area between 1984 and 1994 for gold. Activities included 
 geological mapping, ground magnetic surveys and RC drilling. Gold mineralisation was 
 reported as being within northeast-trending shear zones enclosing quartz veins and stockwork 
 veins. A resource of 120,000 tonnes at 5.0g/t Au was reported but estimated resource grades 
 were not repeated in trial mining.  
 From 1987 to 1991, GMK explored the area with activities including soil and auger sampling, 
 mapping, some magnetic surveys and percussion drilling. The auger sampling program south 
 of Hatter Hill, along lines oriented northeast-southwest 400m apart with sample spacing at 
 40m, identified anomalous gold values and led to the drilling of 92 holes in three locations.  
 In the three drilling areas results above 1g/t Au were recorded as follows:  
 North HHP045 6m @ 13.89g/t Au from 8m 
 Central HHP 006 6m @ 5.45g/t Au from 48m 
 South HHP 002 12m @ 2.23g/t Au from 48m

 The recently completed program comprised 88 RAB holes for 3,467m intersecting anomalous

10.text: The project area has been interpreted as a sequence of intercalated amphibolite, granite and

11.text: minor sediments intruded by pegmatite. The majority of the area is covered by varying

12.text: thicknesses of transported material (dominantly lateritic or quartzose), except in the central

13.text: section of the project area south of Hatters Hill where Tertiary laterites have been stripped and

14.text: the exposed rocks are moderately to strongly weathered.

16.text: Exploration results indicate the presence of a structurally complex greenstone sequence

17.text: containing gold workings with an established production record (>20,00oz at Hatters Hill), and

18.text: elevated nickel-copper geochemistry on the western side of E74/181 in a greenstone

19.text: sequence that extends southeast into the project area.

text:
Text extracted from http://www.gwel.com.au/projects.html 
 The project area has been interpreted as a sequence of intercalated amphibolite, granite and 
 minor sediments intruded by pegmatite. The majority of the area is covered by varying 
 thicknesses of transported material (dominantly lateritic or quartzose), except in the central 
 section of the project area south of Hatters Hill where Tertiary laterites have been stripped and 
 the exposed rocks are moderately to strongly weathered.  
 Exploration results indicate the presence of a structurally complex greenstone sequence 
 containing gold workings with an established production record (>20,00oz at Hatters Hill), and 
 elevated nickel-copper geochemistry on the western side of E74/181 in a greenstone 
 sequence that extends southeast into the project area.

6.text: This systematic exploration identified a broad arcuate anomalous gold zone some 5,000m in

7.text: strike length with gold values frequently above 100ppb and a number in excess of 800ppb. The

8.text: zone is a continuation of the Hatter Hill gold mineralisation and contouring at 100ppb outlines

9.text: both northerly and north westerly trends.

text:
This systematic exploration identified a broad arcuate anomalous gold zone some 5,000m in 
 strike length with gold values frequently above 100ppb and a number in excess of 800ppb. The 
 zone is a continuation of the Hatter Hill gold mineralisation and contouring at 100ppb outlines 
 both northerly and north westerly trends.
